trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a NodeJS Web API accepts tokens from both personal Microsoft Account and work or school accounts.
trans-unit.target: How to build a NodeJS Web API accepts tokens from both personal Microsoft Account and work or school accounts.

trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 Preview: Secure a Web API using node.js
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 Preview: Secure a Web API using node.js

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <link><linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the <link><linkText>Azure Active Directory Developer Guide</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: With the v2.0 app model, you can protecet a Web API using <link><linkText>OAuth 2.0</linkText><title></title></link> access tokens, enabling users with both personal Microsoft account and work or school accounts to securely access your Web API.
trans-unit.target: With the v2.0 app model, you can protecet a Web API using <link><linkText>OAuth 2.0</linkText><title></title></link> access tokens, enabling users with both personal Microsoft account and work or school accounts to securely access your Web API.

trans-unit.source: Passport is authentication middleware for Node.js.
trans-unit.target: Passport is authentication middleware for Node.js.

trans-unit.source: Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based or Resitify web application.
trans-unit.target: Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based or Resitify web application.

trans-unit.source: A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.
trans-unit.target: A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.

trans-unit.source: We have developed a strategy for Microsoft Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: We have developed a strategy for Microsoft Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: We will install this module and then add the Microsoft Azure Active Directory passport-azure-ad plug-in.
trans-unit.target: We will install this module and then add the Microsoft Azure Active Directory passport-azure-ad plug-in.

trans-unit.source: In order to do this, you’ll need to:
trans-unit.target: In order to do this, you’ll need to:

trans-unit.source: Register an application with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Register an application with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Set up your app to use Passport's azure-ad-passport plug-in.
trans-unit.target: Set up your app to use Passport's azure-ad-passport plug-in.

trans-unit.source: Configure a client application to call the To Do List Web API
trans-unit.target: Configure a client application to call the To Do List Web API

trans-unit.source: The code for this tutorial is maintained <link><linkText>on GitHub</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The code for this tutorial is maintained <link><linkText>on GitHub</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To follow along, you can <link><linkText>download the app's skeleton as a .zip</linkText><title></title></link> or clone the skeleton:
trans-unit.target: To follow along, you can <link><linkText>download the app's skeleton as a .zip</linkText><title></title></link> or clone the skeleton:

trans-unit.source: git clone --branch skeleton https://github.com/AzureADQuickStarts/AppModelv2-WebAPI-nodejs.git
trans-unit.target: git clone --branch skeleton https://github.com/AzureADQuickStarts/AppModelv2-WebAPI-nodejs.git

trans-unit.source: The completed application is provided at the end of this tutorial as well.
trans-unit.target: The completed application is provided at the end of this tutorial as well.

trans-unit.source: 1. Register an App
trans-unit.target: 1. Register an App

trans-unit.source: Create a new app at <link><linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title></link>, or follow these <link><linkText>detailed steps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Create a new app at <link><linkText>apps.dev.microsoft.com</linkText><title></title></link>, or follow these <link><linkText>detailed steps</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to:
trans-unit.target: Make sure to:

trans-unit.source: Copy down the Application Id assigned to your app, you'll need it soon.
trans-unit.target: Copy down the Application Id assigned to your app, you'll need it soon.

trans-unit.source: Add the Mobile platform for your app.
trans-unit.target: Add the Mobile platform for your app.

trans-unit.source: Copy down the Redirect URI from the portal.
trans-unit.target: Copy down the Redirect URI from the portal.

trans-unit.source: You must use the default value of urn:ietf:wg:oauth:2.0:oob.
trans-unit.target: You must use the default value of urn:ietf:wg:oauth:2.0:oob.

trans-unit.source: 2: Download node.js for your platform
trans-unit.target: 2: Download node.js for your platform

trans-unit.source: To successfully use this sample, you must have a working installation of Node.js.
trans-unit.target: To successfully use this sample, you must have a working installation of Node.js.

trans-unit.source: Install Node.js from <link><linkText>http://nodejs.org</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Install Node.js from <link><linkText>http://nodejs.org</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: 3: Install MongoDB on to your platform
trans-unit.target: 3: Install MongoDB on to your platform

trans-unit.source: To successfully use this sample, you must have a working installation of MongoDB.
trans-unit.target: To successfully use this sample, you must have a working installation of MongoDB.

trans-unit.source: We will use MongoDB to make our REST API persistant across server instances.
trans-unit.target: We will use MongoDB to make our REST API persistant across server instances.

trans-unit.source: Install MongoDB from <link><linkText>http://mongodb.org</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Install MongoDB from <link><linkText>http://mongodb.org</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This walkthrough assumes that you use the default installation and server endpoints for MongoDB, which at the time of this writing is: mongodb://localhost
trans-unit.target: This walkthrough assumes that you use the default installation and server endpoints for MongoDB, which at the time of this writing is: mongodb://localhost

trans-unit.source: 4: Install the Restify modules in to your Web API
trans-unit.target: 4: Install the Restify modules in to your Web API

trans-unit.source: We will be using Resitfy to build our REST API.
trans-unit.target: We will be using Resitfy to build our REST API.

trans-unit.source: Restify is a minimal and flexible Node.js application framework derived from Express that has a robust set of features for building REST APIs on top of Connect.
trans-unit.target: Restify is a minimal and flexible Node.js application framework derived from Express that has a robust set of features for building REST APIs on top of Connect.

trans-unit.source: Install Restify
trans-unit.target: Install Restify

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread directory.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread directory.

trans-unit.source: If the azuread directory does not exist, create it.
trans-unit.target: If the azuread directory does not exist, create it.

trans-unit.source: cd azuread - or- mkdir azuread;
trans-unit.target: cd azuread - or- mkdir azuread;

trans-unit.source: Type the following command:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command:

trans-unit.source: npm install restify
trans-unit.target: npm install restify

trans-unit.source: This command installs Restify.
trans-unit.target: This command installs Restify.

trans-unit.source: Did you get an error?
trans-unit.target: Did you get an error?

trans-unit.source: When using npm on some operating systems, you may receive an error of Error: EPERM, chmod '/usr/local/bin/..'
trans-unit.target: When using npm on some operating systems, you may receive an error of Error: EPERM, chmod '/usr/local/bin/..'

trans-unit.source: and a request to try running the account as an administrator.
trans-unit.target: and a request to try running the account as an administrator.

trans-unit.source: If this occurs, use the sudo command to run npm at a higher privilege level.
trans-unit.target: If this occurs, use the sudo command to run npm at a higher privilege level.

trans-unit.source: Did you get an error regarding DTrace?
trans-unit.target: Did you get an error regarding DTrace?

trans-unit.source: You may see something like this when installing Restify:
trans-unit.target: You may see something like this when installing Restify:

trans-unit.source: Restify provides a powerful mechanism to trace REST calls using DTrace.
trans-unit.target: Restify provides a powerful mechanism to trace REST calls using DTrace.

trans-unit.source: However, many operating systems do not have DTrace available.
trans-unit.target: However, many operating systems do not have DTrace available.

trans-unit.source: You can safely ignore these errors.
trans-unit.target: You can safely ignore these errors.

trans-unit.source: The output of this command should appear similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The output of this command should appear similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: 5: Install Passport.js into your Web API
trans-unit.target: 5: Install Passport.js into your Web API

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Passport</linkText><title></title></link> is authentication middleware for Node.js.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Passport</linkText><title></title></link> is authentication middleware for Node.js.

trans-unit.source: Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based or Resitify web application.
trans-unit.target: Extremely flexible and modular, Passport can be unobtrusively dropped in to any Express-based or Resitify web application.

trans-unit.source: A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.
trans-unit.target: A comprehensive set of strategies support authentication using a username and password, Facebook, Twitter, and more.

trans-unit.source: We have developed a strategy for Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: We have developed a strategy for Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: We will install this module and then add the Azure Active Directory strategy plug-in.
trans-unit.target: We will install this module and then add the Azure Active Directory strategy plug-in.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread directory.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread directory.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to install passport.js
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to install passport.js

trans-unit.source: npm install passport
trans-unit.target: npm install passport

trans-unit.source: The output of the commadn should appear similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The output of the commadn should appear similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: 6: Add Passport-Azure-AD to your Web API
trans-unit.target: 6: Add Passport-Azure-AD to your Web API

trans-unit.source: Next, we will add the OAuth strategy, using passport-azuread, a suite of strategies that connect Azure Active Directory with Passport.
trans-unit.target: Next, we will add the OAuth strategy, using passport-azuread, a suite of strategies that connect Azure Active Directory with Passport.

trans-unit.source: We will use this strategy for Bearer Tokens in this Rest API sample.
trans-unit.target: We will use this strategy for Bearer Tokens in this Rest API sample.

trans-unit.source: Although OAuth2 provides a framework in which any known token type can be issued, only certain token types have gained wide-spread use.
trans-unit.target: Although OAuth2 provides a framework in which any known token type can be issued, only certain token types have gained wide-spread use.

trans-unit.source: For protecting endpoints, that has turned out to be Bearer Tokens.
trans-unit.target: For protecting endpoints, that has turned out to be Bearer Tokens.

trans-unit.source: Bearer tokens are the most widely issued type of token in OAuth2, and many implementations assume that bearer tokens are the only type of token issued.
trans-unit.target: Bearer tokens are the most widely issued type of token in OAuth2, and many implementations assume that bearer tokens are the only type of token issued.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread directory
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread directory

trans-unit.source: Type the following command to install Passport.js passport-azure-ad module:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command to install Passport.js passport-azure-ad module:

trans-unit.source: npm install passport-azure-ad
trans-unit.target: npm install passport-azure-ad

trans-unit.source: The output of the command should appear similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The output of the command should appear similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: passport-azure-ad@1.0.0 node_modules/passport-azure-ad
trans-unit.target: passport-azure-ad@1.0.0 node_modules/passport-azure-ad

trans-unit.source: ├── passport-http-bearer@1.0.1 (passport-strategy@1.0.0)
trans-unit.target: ├── passport-http-bearer@1.0.1 (passport-strategy@1.0.0)

trans-unit.source: ├── underscore@1.8.3
trans-unit.target: ├── underscore@1.8.3

trans-unit.source: ├── jsonwebtoken@5.0.2
trans-unit.target: ├── jsonwebtoken@5.0.2

trans-unit.source: ├── xml-crypto@0.5.27 (xpath.js@1.0.6)
trans-unit.target: ├── xml-crypto@0.5.27 (xpath.js@1.0.6)

trans-unit.source: ├── request@2.58.0 (caseless@0.10.0, aws-sign2@0.5.0, forever-agent@0.6.1, stringstream@0.0.4, tunnel-agent@0.4.1, oauth-sign@0.8.0, isstream@0.1.2, extend@2.0.1, json-stringify-safe@5.0.1, node-uuid@1.4.3, qs@3.1.0, combined-stream@1.0.5, mime-types@2.0.14, form-data@1.0.0-rc1, http-signature@0.11.0, bl@0.9.4, tough-cookie@2.0.0, hawk@2.3.1, har-validator@1.8.0)
trans-unit.target: ├── request@2.58.0 (caseless@0.10.0, aws-sign2@0.5.0, forever-agent@0.6.1, stringstream@0.0.4, tunnel-agent@0.4.1, oauth-sign@0.8.0, isstream@0.1.2, extend@2.0.1, json-stringify-safe@5.0.1, node-uuid@1.4.3, qs@3.1.0, combined-stream@1.0.5, mime-types@2.0.14, form-data@1.0.0-rc1, http-signature@0.11.0, bl@0.9.4, tough-cookie@2.0.0, hawk@2.3.1, har-validator@1.8.0)

trans-unit.source: └── xml2js@0.4.9 (sax@0.6.1, xmlbuilder@2.6.4)
trans-unit.target: └── xml2js@0.4.9 (sax@0.6.1, xmlbuilder@2.6.4)

trans-unit.source: 7: Add MongoDB modules to your Web API
trans-unit.target: 7: Add MongoDB modules to your Web API

trans-unit.source: We will be using MongoDB as our datastore For that reason, we need to install both the widely used plug-in to manage models and schemas called Mongoose, as well as the database driver for MongoDB, also called MongoDB.
trans-unit.target: We will be using MongoDB as our datastore For that reason, we need to install both the widely used plug-in to manage models and schemas called Mongoose, as well as the database driver for MongoDB, also called MongoDB.

trans-unit.source: npm install mongoose
trans-unit.target: npm install mongoose

trans-unit.source: npm install mongodb
trans-unit.target: npm install mongodb

trans-unit.source: 8: Install additional modules
trans-unit.target: 8: Install additional modules

trans-unit.source: Next, we'll install the remaining required modules.
trans-unit.target: Next, we'll install the remaining required modules.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:

trans-unit.source: cd azuread
trans-unit.target: cd azuread

trans-unit.source: Enter the following commands to install the following modules in your node_modules directory:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following commands to install the following modules in your node_modules directory:

trans-unit.target: npm install crypto

trans-unit.source: npm install assert-plus
trans-unit.target: npm install assert-plus

trans-unit.source: npm install posix-getopt
trans-unit.target: npm install posix-getopt

trans-unit.source: npm install util
trans-unit.target: npm install util

trans-unit.source: npm install path
trans-unit.target: npm install path

trans-unit.source: npm install connect
trans-unit.target: npm install connect

trans-unit.source: npm install xml-crypto
trans-unit.target: npm install xml-crypto

trans-unit.source: npm install xml2js
trans-unit.target: npm install xml2js

trans-unit.source: npm install xmldom
trans-unit.target: npm install xmldom

trans-unit.source: npm install async
trans-unit.target: npm install async

trans-unit.source: npm install request
trans-unit.target: npm install request

trans-unit.source: npm install underscore
trans-unit.target: npm install underscore

trans-unit.source: npm install grunt-contrib-jshint@0.1.1
trans-unit.target: npm install grunt-contrib-jshint@0.1.1

trans-unit.source: npm install grunt-contrib-nodeunit@0.1.2
trans-unit.target: npm install grunt-contrib-nodeunit@0.1.2

trans-unit.source: npm install grunt-contrib-watch@0.2.0
trans-unit.target: npm install grunt-contrib-watch@0.2.0

trans-unit.source: npm install grunt@0.4.1
trans-unit.target: npm install grunt@0.4.1

trans-unit.source: npm install xtend@2.0.3
trans-unit.target: npm install xtend@2.0.3

trans-unit.source: npm install bunyan
trans-unit.target: npm install bunyan

trans-unit.source: npm update
trans-unit.target: npm update

trans-unit.source: 9: Create a server.js with your dependencies
trans-unit.target: 9: Create a server.js with your dependencies

trans-unit.source: The server.js file will be providing the majority of our functionality for our Web API server.
trans-unit.target: The server.js file will be providing the majority of our functionality for our Web API server.

trans-unit.source: We will be adding most of our code to this file.
trans-unit.target: We will be adding most of our code to this file.

trans-unit.source: For production purposes you would refactor the functionality in to smaller files, such as separate routes and controllers.
trans-unit.target: For production purposes you would refactor the functionality in to smaller files, such as separate routes and controllers.

trans-unit.source: For the purpose of this demo we will use server.js for this functionality.
trans-unit.target: For the purpose of this demo we will use server.js for this functionality.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:

trans-unit.source: cd azuread
trans-unit.target: cd azuread

trans-unit.source: Create a server.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information:
trans-unit.target: Create a server.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information:

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: We will return to it shortly.
trans-unit.target: We will return to it shortly.

trans-unit.source: 10: Create a config file to store your Azure AD settings
trans-unit.target: 10: Create a config file to store your Azure AD settings

trans-unit.source: This code file passes the configuration parameters from your Azure Active Directory Portal to Passport.js.
trans-unit.target: This code file passes the configuration parameters from your Azure Active Directory Portal to Passport.js.

trans-unit.source: You created these configuration values when you added the Web API to the portal in the first part of the walkthrough.
trans-unit.target: You created these configuration values when you added the Web API to the portal in the first part of the walkthrough.

trans-unit.source: We will explain what to put in the values of these parameters after you've copied the code.
trans-unit.target: We will explain what to put in the values of these parameters after you've copied the code.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:

trans-unit.source: cd azuread
trans-unit.target: cd azuread

trans-unit.source: Create a config.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information:
trans-unit.target: Create a config.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information:

trans-unit.source: Required Values
trans-unit.target: Required Values

trans-unit.source: IdentityMetadata: This is where passport-azure-ad will look for your configuration data for the IdP as well as the keys to validate the JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: IdentityMetadata: This is where passport-azure-ad will look for your configuration data for the IdP as well as the keys to validate the JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: You probably do not want to change this if using Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You probably do not want to change this if using Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: audience: Your redirect URI from the portal.
trans-unit.target: audience: Your redirect URI from the portal.

trans-unit.source: We roll our keys at frequent intervals.
trans-unit.target: We roll our keys at frequent intervals.

trans-unit.source: Please ensure that you are always pulling from the "openid_keys" URL and that the app can access the internet.
trans-unit.target: Please ensure that you are always pulling from the "openid_keys" URL and that the app can access the internet.

trans-unit.source: 11: Add configuration to your server.js file
trans-unit.target: 11: Add configuration to your server.js file

trans-unit.source: We need to read these values from the Config file you just created across our application.
trans-unit.target: We need to read these values from the Config file you just created across our application.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we simply add the .config file as a required resource in our application and then set the global variables to those in the config.js document
trans-unit.target: To do this, we simply add the .config file as a required resource in our application and then set the global variables to those in the config.js document

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:

trans-unit.source: cd azuread
trans-unit.target: cd azuread

trans-unit.source: Open your server.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information:
trans-unit.target: Open your server.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information:

trans-unit.source: Then, add a new section to server.js with the following code:
trans-unit.target: Then, add a new section to server.js with the following code:

trans-unit.source: Step 12: Add The MongoDB Model and Schema Information using Moongoose
trans-unit.target: Step 12: Add The MongoDB Model and Schema Information using Moongoose

trans-unit.source: Now all this preparation is going to start paying off as we wind these three files together in to a REST API service.
trans-unit.target: Now all this preparation is going to start paying off as we wind these three files together in to a REST API service.

trans-unit.source: For this walkthrough we will be using MongoDB to store our Tasks as discussed in *Step 4*.
trans-unit.target: For this walkthrough we will be using MongoDB to store our Tasks as discussed in *Step 4*.

trans-unit.source: If you recall from the config.js file we created in Step 11, we called our database tasklist, as that was what we put at the end of our mogoose_auth_local connection URL.
trans-unit.target: If you recall from the config.js file we created in Step 11, we called our database tasklist, as that was what we put at the end of our mogoose_auth_local connection URL.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to create this database beforehand in MongoDB, it will create this for us on first run of our server application (assuming it does not already exist).
trans-unit.target: You don't need to create this database beforehand in MongoDB, it will create this for us on first run of our server application (assuming it does not already exist).

trans-unit.source: Now that we've told the server what MongoDB database we'd like to use, we need to write some additional code to create the model and schema for our server's Tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that we've told the server what MongoDB database we'd like to use, we need to write some additional code to create the model and schema for our server's Tasks.

trans-unit.source: Discussion of the model
trans-unit.target: Discussion of the model

trans-unit.source: Our Schema model is very simple, and you expand it as required.
trans-unit.target: Our Schema model is very simple, and you expand it as required.

trans-unit.source: NAME - The name of who is assigned to the task.
trans-unit.target: NAME - The name of who is assigned to the task.

trans-unit.source: A *String*
trans-unit.target: A *String*

trans-unit.source: TASK - The task itself.
trans-unit.target: TASK - The task itself.

trans-unit.source: A *String*
trans-unit.target: A *String*

trans-unit.source: DATE - The date that the task is due.
trans-unit.target: DATE - The date that the task is due.

trans-unit.source: A *DATETIME*
trans-unit.target: A *DATETIME*

trans-unit.source: COMPLETED - If the Task is completed or not.
trans-unit.target: COMPLETED - If the Task is completed or not.

trans-unit.source: A *BOOLEAN*
trans-unit.target: A *BOOLEAN*

trans-unit.source: Creating the schema in the code
trans-unit.target: Creating the schema in the code

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:

trans-unit.source: cd azuread
trans-unit.target: cd azuread

trans-unit.source: Open your server.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information below the configuration entry:
trans-unit.target: Open your server.js file in our favorite editor and add the following information below the configuration entry:

trans-unit.source: This will connect to the MongoDB server and hand back a Schema object to us.
trans-unit.target: This will connect to the MongoDB server and hand back a Schema object to us.

trans-unit.source: Using the Schema, create our model in the code
trans-unit.target: Using the Schema, create our model in the code

trans-unit.source: Below the code you wrote above, add the following code:
trans-unit.target: Below the code you wrote above, add the following code:

trans-unit.source: As you can tell from the code, we create our Schema and then create a model object we will use to store our data throughout the code when we define our *Routes*.
trans-unit.target: As you can tell from the code, we create our Schema and then create a model object we will use to store our data throughout the code when we define our *Routes*.

trans-unit.source: Step 13: Add our Routes for our Task REST API server
trans-unit.target: Step 13: Add our Routes for our Task REST API server

trans-unit.source: Now that we have a database model to work with, let's add the routes we will use for our REST API server.
trans-unit.target: Now that we have a database model to work with, let's add the routes we will use for our REST API server.

trans-unit.source: About Routes in Restify
trans-unit.target: About Routes in Restify

trans-unit.source: Routes work in Restify in the exact same way they do using the Express stack.
trans-unit.target: Routes work in Restify in the exact same way they do using the Express stack.

trans-unit.source: You define routes using the URI that you expect the client applicaitons to call.
trans-unit.target: You define routes using the URI that you expect the client applicaitons to call.

trans-unit.source: Usually, you define your routes in a separate file.
trans-unit.target: Usually, you define your routes in a separate file.

trans-unit.source: For our purposes, we will put our routes in the server.js file.
trans-unit.target: For our purposes, we will put our routes in the server.js file.

trans-unit.source: We recommend you factor these in to their own file for production use.
trans-unit.target: We recommend you factor these in to their own file for production use.

trans-unit.target: A typical pattern for a Restify Route is:

trans-unit.source: Resitfy (and Express) provide much deeper functionaltiy such as defining application types and doing complex routing across different endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Resitfy (and Express) provide much deeper functionaltiy such as defining application types and doing complex routing across different endpoints.

trans-unit.source: For our purposes, we will keep these routes very simply.
trans-unit.target: For our purposes, we will keep these routes very simply.

trans-unit.source: Test out your server before we add authentication
trans-unit.target: Test out your server before we add authentication

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to do this is by using curl in a command line.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to do this is by using curl in a command line.

trans-unit.source: Before we do that, we need a simple utility that allows us to parse output as JSON.
trans-unit.target: Before we do that, we need a simple utility that allows us to parse output as JSON.

trans-unit.source: To do that, install the json tool as all the examples below use that.
trans-unit.target: To do that, install the json tool as all the examples below use that.

trans-unit.source: $npm install -g jsontool
trans-unit.target: $npm install -g jsontool

trans-unit.source: This installs the JSON tool globally.
trans-unit.target: This installs the JSON tool globally.

trans-unit.source: Now that we’ve accomplished that – let’s play with the server:
trans-unit.target: Now that we’ve accomplished that – let’s play with the server:

trans-unit.source: First, make sure that your monogoDB isntance is running..
trans-unit.target: First, make sure that your monogoDB isntance is running..

trans-unit.source: $sudo mongod
trans-unit.target: $sudo mongod

trans-unit.source: Then, change to the directory and start curling..
trans-unit.target: Then, change to the directory and start curling..

trans-unit.source: $ cd azuread
trans-unit.target: $ cd azuread

trans-unit.source: $ node server.js
trans-unit.target: $ node server.js

trans-unit.source: $ curl -isS http://127.0.0.1:8080 | json
trans-unit.target: $ curl -isS http://127.0.0.1:8080 | json

trans-unit.source: Then, we can add a task this way:
trans-unit.target: Then, we can add a task this way:

trans-unit.source: $ curl -isS -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8888/tasks/brandon/Hello
trans-unit.target: $ curl -isS -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8888/tasks/brandon/Hello

trans-unit.source: The response should be:
trans-unit.target: The response should be:

trans-unit.source: And we can list tasks for Brandon this way:
trans-unit.target: And we can list tasks for Brandon this way:

trans-unit.source: $ curl -isS http://127.0.0.1:8080/tasks/brandon/
trans-unit.target: $ curl -isS http://127.0.0.1:8080/tasks/brandon/

trans-unit.source: If all this works out, we are ready to add OAuth to the REST API server.
trans-unit.target: If all this works out, we are ready to add OAuth to the REST API server.

trans-unit.source: You have a REST API server with MongoDB!
trans-unit.target: You have a REST API server with MongoDB!

trans-unit.target: 17: Add Authentication to our REST API Server

trans-unit.target: Now that we have a running REST API (congrats, btw!)

trans-unit.source: let's get to making it useful against Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: let's get to making it useful against Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the azuread folder if not already there:

trans-unit.source: cd azuread
trans-unit.target: cd azuread

trans-unit.source: 1: Use the oidcbearerstrategy that is included with passport-azure-ad
trans-unit.target: 1: Use the oidcbearerstrategy that is included with passport-azure-ad

trans-unit.source: So far we have built a typical REST TODO server without any kind of authorization.
trans-unit.target: So far we have built a typical REST TODO server without any kind of authorization.

trans-unit.source: This is where we start putting that together.
trans-unit.target: This is where we start putting that together.

trans-unit.source: First, we need to indicate that we want to use Passport.
trans-unit.target: First, we need to indicate that we want to use Passport.

trans-unit.source: Put this right after your other server configuration:
trans-unit.target: Put this right after your other server configuration:

trans-unit.source: When writing APIs you should always link the data to something unique from the token that the user can’t spoof.
trans-unit.target: When writing APIs you should always link the data to something unique from the token that the user can’t spoof.

trans-unit.source: When this server stores TODO items, it stores them based on the subscription ID of the user in the token (called through token.sub) which we put in the “owner” field.
trans-unit.target: When this server stores TODO items, it stores them based on the subscription ID of the user in the token (called through token.sub) which we put in the “owner” field.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that only that user can access his TODOs and no one else can access the TODOs entered.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that only that user can access his TODOs and no one else can access the TODOs entered.

trans-unit.source: There is no exposure in the API of “owner” so an external user can request other’s TODOs even if they are authenticated.
trans-unit.target: There is no exposure in the API of “owner” so an external user can request other’s TODOs even if they are authenticated.

trans-unit.source: Next, let’s use the Open ID Connect Bearer strategy that comes with passport-azure-ad.
trans-unit.target: Next, let’s use the Open ID Connect Bearer strategy that comes with passport-azure-ad.

trans-unit.source: Just look at the code for now, I’ll explain it shortly.
trans-unit.target: Just look at the code for now, I’ll explain it shortly.

trans-unit.source: Put this after what you pated above:
trans-unit.target: Put this after what you pated above:

trans-unit.source: Passport uses a similar pattern for all it’s Strategies (Twitter, Facebook, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Passport uses a similar pattern for all it’s Strategies (Twitter, Facebook, etc.)

trans-unit.source: that all Strategy writers adhere to.
trans-unit.target: that all Strategy writers adhere to.

trans-unit.source: Looking at the strategy you see we pass it a function() that has a token and a done as the parameters.
trans-unit.target: Looking at the strategy you see we pass it a function() that has a token and a done as the parameters.

trans-unit.source: The strategy will dutifully come back to us once it does all it’s work.
trans-unit.target: The strategy will dutifully come back to us once it does all it’s work.

trans-unit.source: Once it does we’ll want to store the user and stash the token so we won’t need to ask for it again.
trans-unit.target: Once it does we’ll want to store the user and stash the token so we won’t need to ask for it again.

trans-unit.source: The code above takes any user that happens to authenticate to our server.
trans-unit.target: The code above takes any user that happens to authenticate to our server.

trans-unit.source: This is known as auto registration.
trans-unit.target: This is known as auto registration.

trans-unit.source: In production servers you wouldn’t want to let anyone in without first having them go through a registration process you decide.
trans-unit.target: In production servers you wouldn’t want to let anyone in without first having them go through a registration process you decide.

trans-unit.source: This is usually the pattern you see in consumer apps who allow you to register with Facebook but then ask you to fill out additional information.
trans-unit.target: This is usually the pattern you see in consumer apps who allow you to register with Facebook but then ask you to fill out additional information.

trans-unit.source: If this wasn’t a command line program, we could have just extracted the email from the token object that is returned and then asked them to fill out additional information.
trans-unit.target: If this wasn’t a command line program, we could have just extracted the email from the token object that is returned and then asked them to fill out additional information.

trans-unit.source: Since this is a test server we simply add them to the in-memory database.
trans-unit.target: Since this is a test server we simply add them to the in-memory database.

trans-unit.target: 2. Finally, protect some endpoints

trans-unit.source: You protect endpoints by specifying the passport.authenticate() call with the protocol you wish to use.
trans-unit.target: You protect endpoints by specifying the passport.authenticate() call with the protocol you wish to use.

trans-unit.target: Let's use curl again to see if we now have OAuth2 protection against our endpoints.

trans-unit.target: We will do this before runnning any of our client SDKs against this endpoint.

trans-unit.target: The headers returned should be enough to tell us we are down the right path.

trans-unit.target: First, make sure that your monogoDB isntance is running..

trans-unit.target: Then, change to the directory and start curling..

trans-unit.source: Try a basic POST:
trans-unit.target: Try a basic POST:

trans-unit.source: $ curl -isS -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/tasks/brandon/Hello
trans-unit.target: $ curl -isS -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/tasks/brandon/Hello

trans-unit.source: A 401 is the response you are looking for here, as that indicates that the Passport layer is trying to redirect to the authorize endpoint, which is exactly what you want.
trans-unit.target: A 401 is the response you are looking for here, as that indicates that the Passport layer is trying to redirect to the authorize endpoint, which is exactly what you want.
